mdx.body:
## Preface: I'm an AI naysayer I've been a software engineer for almost 7 years now. As someone who is self-taught, I'm open to unconventional experiences and methods when it comes to building something. I believe that how someone builds something is a reflection of their previous experiences and mistakes. When it comes to AI generated code, you would think that the experiences and mistakes of every piece of training data would result in code generation that is sound and thoughtful. But that's just the thing: AI doesn't think. These LLMs are just prediction models at their core. One could argue that the human brain is just one large prediction model and I could agree with that, but the difference is that we have so much more context than LLMs can support. We have _years_ of context. I also believe there are _consequences_ to using AI, whether for learning or productivity and this extends past just software engineering. Here are a few of those trade offs that we should be considering: 1. Environmental impacts - we don't know how much of a toll the infrastructure to support model training and model hosting is going to take on natural resources, but we can [estimate at this point](https://apnews.com/article/ai-data-center-climate-impact-environment-c6218681ffdbad5bf427b47347fddcb9) and the energy usage is very alarming. More and more companies are forcing AI on people, both employees and products, which compounds these effects. 2. Familiarity is built during the development process and is paramount to being able to design other features, find bugs, and answer questions about what you've produced. The more code that's generated, the less familiar you are with it. 3. I believe we learn best by making mistakes. By using LLMs, mistakes are masked and "solved" by the LLM. We lose all of those valuable learning opportunities. So I don't use LLMs to write functional code. The cost is too great. ## Vibe coding At this point, we all know what vibe coding is. I like to stay on top of new technologies and from a professional perspective, I think it would be irresponsible to never try using an LLM to write _some_ code, so why not all of it for a tiny project? My partner is planning on getting her driving license soon (not because she's a teenager, to be clear) and so I wanted to help her study for the Washington state knowledge test which is required in addition to the driving test. The resources out there to study are not great: - [Washington's own guide](https://dol.wa.gov/driver-licenses-and-permits/driver-training-and-testing/driver-guides) is almost 200 page pdf - [Other sites](https://driving-tests.org/washington/) require payment and are just practice driving tests One good resource I found was [Defensive Driving School's "Numbers to Know" PDF](https://driving-school.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Numbers-to-Know.pdf). What I want is a site for studying with flashcards and then randomly generated practice tests. Sounds simple enough, the perfect opportunity to give vibe coding a shot! **Here are my requirements:** - Web application - Flashcards that can be shuffled with questions and answers for the WA DOL knowledge test - 40 question practice test, multiple choice, shuffled questions ### Set up I don't like subscriptions. Luckily, most AI providers offer API keys which use credits that are one time purchases. There are also two main methods of vibe coding that I'm aware of: 1. In an IDE like [Cursor](https://cursor.com/) or [Windsurf](https://windsurf.com/) 2. A terminal agent like [Claude code](https://claudecode.io/) There are some browser based agents like [v0](https://v0.app/), but I would like a bit of a hand in some of the source code. As for the type of application, a simple [vite](https://vite.dev/) [React](https://react.dev/) app with [Typescript](https://www.typescriptlang.org/) is what I want. The agent I decided to go with is [OpenCode](https://opencode.ai/) which is a terminal based agent that I can use an API key with, perfect! I opted to use [Claude Sonnet 4.5](https://www.anthropic.com/news/claude-sonnet-4-5) for this project as I've heard more good things about Claude than other models. **So here's the summary of the setup:** - Vite React/TS app - PDF driver's guide from [WA DOL site](https://dol.wa.gov/driver-licenses-and-permits/driver-training-and-testing/driver-guides) - [Numbers to know from Defensive Driving School](https://driving-school.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Numbers-to-Know.pdf) - Opencode agent - Claude Sonnet 4.5 for model For fun, I planned on not looking at **any code** that the agent generates until the project is complete. Project structure is also up to the agent. ### Initial prompt Here was my initial prompt: > I want to create a flashcard app for the washington state department of licensing knowledge test. > There are two pdfs in this repo, one is the numbers to know, the second is the resource from the > state containing all rules of the road. I want the bank of questions and answers in json format > for ease of auditing. My OpenCode Claude agent started off attempting to read the PDF and opted for writing a Python script to read the PDF since I have a version of Python installed. ![Vibe coding looking for pdf extraction tool](images/vibe-coding_pdftotext.png) This did not work as the library that the agent wanted to use was not installed. The agent then opted to write a bash script to read the PDF manually which also didn't work. Not a great start. The agent then attempted _another_ Python script and failed as expected. As a last resort, the agent asked me to manually input the data as seen above. I ended up installing `pdftotext` myself and letting the agent know that I had installed it. With the expected output, the agent created the question bank successfully from the "Numbers to Know" PDF. I later asked to pull advanced questions from the full guide, but the PDF was too big. Luckily, the WA DOL site had an html text only version that was simplified. The agent was able to parse out a total of 54 questions and I ended up just using this instead of the "Numbers to Know" questions as there was some significant overlap. ### UI Next step was to get some flashcard UI going and I wanted the agent to use [shadcn](https://ui.shadcn.com/) in conjunction with [tailwindcss](https://tailwindcss.com/), modern web framework tools. I purposefully did not include these in my project setup to see how the agent would install them. This went mostly smooth. The agent had a hard time with the initialization of tailwind with my package manager `pnpm` and ended up creating the config manually: ![Vibe coding installing Tailwindcss](images/vibe-coding_tailwind-install.png) Later, I learned that this manual Tailwind config was incorrect for the version we had installed and the config had to be updated again: ![Vibe coding updating Tailwind config](images/vibe-coding_update-tailwind.png) Another interesting, uh, "choice" that the agent made was to just manually create the shadcn components rather than just follow the typical component installation. For those unfamiliar with shadcn, components are typically installed via their [CLI tool](https://ui.shadcn.com/docs/installation/vite) which does just clone components into your repository. Did the agent create the correct components? Not sure yet. I'll look at the code at the end to compare. ![Vibe coding installing shadcn](images/vibe-coding_shadcn.png) From here on out, development consisted of: - Some minor back and forth, tuning the UI for better UX - Adding animations - Fixing bugs (typically one to three prompts) - The agent's overconfident "fixed!" responses ### Practice test The last feature to vibe in was the practice test feature. This takes the flashcards and turns them into multiple choice questions with reasonable, similar answers compared to the correct answer. Here, the agent got the practice test UI up and going with ease. The content however, was a bit of a struggle. For some reason, the agent decided to dynamically generate question answers for every test. ![Vibe coding generate question answers](images/vibe-coding_plan.png) This had some interesting results:
![Vibe coding bad answers1](images/vibe-coding_bad-answers1.png) ![Vibe coding bad answers2](images/vibe-coding_bad-answers2.png)
I prompted for iteration on this, and the agent ended up tweaking its algorithm and that resulted in an infinite loop. I ended up having to prompt it to generate the similar answers on its own and store those in the JSON question bank. That worked much better. One thing you might have noticed is that I haven't shared much of what the UI _looks_ like or the iterations that it's been through. There's one thing that these agents could do better which is version control. Do I want these agents to be able to access `git`? Not really, but they already have access (with permission) to run commands in a terminal so why not `git`? If I could say "develop on this one branch and commit frequently", I could be able to go back and look at how the UI has progressed. Part of that is on me for not taking screenshots though so I won't count this against the agent. ### Deployment So far we have had the agent do the "backend" and the frontend, so let's have it do the deployment as well. I want to be able to deploy this to Github pages and deploy to my local network with a Docker container. I understand this is probably out of the realm that a normal vibe-coder would want, but I don't want to pay for a hosting solution. The agent claims to have built out the two deployment options that I requested so let's test them out. ![Vibe coding deployment](images/vibe-coding_deployment.png) Starting with the Docker container, the Dockerfile did not result in a successful local deployment. Pasting in the error message, the agent believed that the error has to do with routing via the base path. Look at that! The Docker container now works. Hosting this application locally is another story. It has more to do with my local network setup rather than the application, so I'll skip that here now that I have a working container. As for Github pages, that deployment is next. I committed the changes to see what happens. ![Vibe coding github deployment failure](images/vibe-coding_github-failure.png) Seems like a relatively simple error. I pasted the results into opencode and commit the edits. Drum roll please... success! The app was built and deployed. We can finally call this project "done" since it's now live. See the application [here](https://balake.github.io/wadol-knowledge-test/)! Note that any changes made since this post will be only to correct questions or facts presented as I doubt the agent parsed things 100% factually. Here are some screenshots of the application also as proof. ![Vibe coding flashcard](images/vibe-coding_flashcard.png) ![Vibe coding question](images/vibe-coding_question.png) Bonus: I took the test. Maybe I should study a bit ü´†. Worth noting here passing is 80%, not 70%. Not sure where the agent got that, but I will be going through and verifying all the questions and answers before handing this off to my partner. ![Vibe coding score](images/vibe-coding_score.png) ## The code Let's look at the code that the agent generated with Claude Sonnet 4.5. I haven't looked at it yet, so I'm quite curious. Feel free to browse the code yourself [here](https://github.com/Balake/wadol-knowledge-test). ### Structure Right off the bat, structure for this project appears to be mostly in order. There are some interesting artifacts including the `App.css` file from the vite setup that is no longer used. It's generally good that these agents don't clean up files as that reduces the chance of removing files that are important. One thing that I would have done differently structure-wise is setup a directory for component containers rather than just "components", but that's a bit pedantic. I also would have split some of the app logic out into a `React.context` for some separation of concerns. Structure is somewhat subjective and this app is not very complicated, so I give agent generated structure: üëç ![Vibe coding structure](images/vibe-coding_structure.png) I also never specified installing `eslint`, so that's an interesting addition, but overall, a net positive here. I know the agent used `eslint` to verify some of its work. ### UI I'll preface this next section with: I'm not a frontend engineer. I do everything, but frontend is where I feel like I know the least, especially with modern web frameworks. The first question I have is: did the agent get the shadcn components correct? Rather than using the install tool from shadcn, the agent just generated the components itself. Here is the generated `Badge` component: ```typescript import * as React from "react" import { cva, type VariantProps } from "class-variance-authority" import { cn } from "@/lib/utils.ts" const badgeVariants = cva( "inline-flex items-center rounded-md border border-slate-200 px-2.5 py-0.5 text-xs font-semibold transition-colors focus:outline-none focus:ring-2 focus:ring-slate-950 focus:ring-offset-2", { variants: { variant: { default: "border-transparent bg-slate-900 text-slate-50 shadow hover:bg-slate-900/80", secondary: "border-transparent bg-slate-100 text-slate-900 hover:bg-slate-100/80", outline: "text-slate-950", }, }, defaultVariants: { variant: "default", }, } ) export interface BadgeProps extends React.HTMLAttributes, VariantProps {} function Badge({ className, variant, ...props }: BadgeProps) { return (
) } export { Badge } ``` And here is the `Badge` from shadcn: ```typescript import * as React from "react" import { Slot } from "@radix-ui/react-slot" import { cva, type VariantProps } from "class-variance-authority" import { cn } from "@/lib/utils" const badgeVariants = cva( "inline-flex items-center justify-center rounded-md border px-2 py-0.5 text-xs font-medium w-fit whitespace-nowrap shrink-0 [&>svg]:size-3 gap-1 [&>svg]:pointer-events-none focus-visible:border-ring focus-visible:ring-ring/50 focus-visible:ring-[3px] aria-invalid:ring-destructive/20 dark:aria-invalid:ring-destructive/40 aria-invalid:border-destructive transition-[color,box-shadow] overflow-hidden", { variants: { variant: { default: "border-transparent bg-primary text-primary-foreground [a&]:hover:bg-primary/90", secondary: "border-transparent bg-secondary text-secondary-foreground [a&]:hover:bg-secondary/90", destructive: "border-transparent bg-destructive text-white [a&]:hover:bg-destructive/90 focus-visible:ring-destructive/20 dark:focus-visible:ring-destructive/40 dark:bg-destructive/60", outline: "text-foreground [a&]:hover:bg-accent [a&]:hover:text-accent-foreground", }, }, defaultVariants: { variant: "default", }, } ) function Badge({ className, variant, asChild = false, ...props }: React.ComponentProps<"span"> & VariantProps & { asChild?: boolean }) { const Comp = asChild ? Slot : "span" return ( ) } export { Badge, badgeVariants } ``` Alright so the component that the agent generated is quite a bit different than the shadcn version. Here are some of the differences that I notice on the agent version: - The `destructive` variant is missing from the `Badge` variants - The default variant styles are different: - Manually specifies colors rather than use Tailwind variables like `primary` or `secondary` - Missing the `transition` properties - Different padding values - Doesn't support anchor (``) tags - Support for `asChild` is missing which is quite useful. - Exporting the `badgeVariants` is missing as well which is useful for types Here's some [additional reading](https://medium.com/@bryanmylee/aschild-in-react-svelte-vue-and-solid-for-render-delegation-645c73650ced) on the `asChild` pattern and why it's important. This is just the first component. I suspect that the others will be similar. I will note that shadcn components can be customized, but I asked the agent for just default shadcn components. The manual color specifications that the agent did in these components got me curious... Maybe there isn't a Tailwind theme? And there's not. Whose fault would that be? Every frontend project that I've worked on has used a Tailwind theme. The theme is a [core concept](https://tailwindcss.com/docs/theme) of Tailwind. This is a clear miss by the agent. ### Data Let's take a look at the underlying data structure powering this app. There's not a ton here to look at, but still worth taking a peek. ```json { "title": "Washington State Driver's License - Advanced Knowledge", "categories": [ { "id": "stopping-distances", "name": "Stopping & Following Distances", "questions": [ { "id": "stop-1", "question": "How long does it take a loaded truck with properly adjusted brakes, traveling at 55 mph, to come to a complete stop?", "answer": "450", "unit": "feet", "wrongAnswers": ["300 feet", "400 feet", "500 feet"] }, { "id": "stop-2", "question": "At what distance should you usually be able to stop within the glow of your headlights?", "answer": "400", "unit": "feet", "wrongAnswers": ["300 feet", "500 feet", "600 feet"] }, { "id": "stop-3", "question": "How far ahead should you pick out a marker (like a road sign) when counting seconds for following distance?", "answer": "15", "unit": "seconds", "wrongAnswers": ["10 seconds", "12 seconds", "20 seconds"] }, { "id": "stop-4", "question": "What is the minimum distance you should stop from the nearest rail of a railroad crossing?", "answer": "15", "unit": "feet", "wrongAnswers": ["10 feet", "20 feet", "25 feet"] }, { "id": "stop-5", "question": "What is the maximum distance you should stop from the nearest rail of a railroad crossing?", "answer": "50", "unit": "feet", "wrongAnswers": ["40 feet", "60 feet", "75 feet"] } ] }, ... ] } ``` Overall, not bad. Is this how I would have done it? No, I don't think so, but this gets the job done and it's easy enough to add new questions or edit them. I do think that specifically the `unit` property is interesting as it's not used outside of formatting the answer. Why not just have that be part of the answer? I'm not sure what the point of it is. ## Conclusion The agent definitely generated some code. No attempt was made at cleanup. What I asked for vs what I got was never the first attempt, but that's true for any engineering project. I'm disappointed in the agent not following shadcn or Tailwind standards. I've heard others say these agents operate intellectually at a junior level, and I think that's a fair comparison. One final aspect of this process that is worth considering is _time_ and _cost_. These agents are supposed to save us time right? Well I'm not convinced that any time was saved. I think this is something that I could have done in a couple hours. I still have to go through and verify all the questions and answers before sharing with my partner. The following images are the _cost_ associated with building this app, taken from claude console:
![Vibe coding tokens](images/vibe-coding_tokens.png) ![Vibe coding cost](images/vibe-coding_cost.png)
Could I have prompted better? Absolutely. Did I learn anything while doing this? I learned that I won't be vibe coding ever again, reinforcing my AI skepticism. I feel like I actively contributed to the climate crisis. The hype is not real. Maybe it will be in the future, but today is not that day. \- Balake, not a vibe coder

frontmatter.title: First time vibe coding ü§î
frontmatter.description: As an AI naysayer, I try vibe coding for the first time. Does AI gain any brownie points?
